comments.commentBody:
What's happened is reprehensible. However, a couple of things don't seem to be reflected upon. 1. As the public, our tacit approval to publishing extremely private and personal matters that results in the circulation numbers. How is the grief of a family who's lost their dear one or the illness of a child (the fact that the parent is x or y is irrelevant) publishing-worthy? 2. There is a presumption of guilt across all Murdoch's businesses (contrary to how the law functions) and some may inherently have no scope of "hacking" e g distribution of television feeds (as opposed to content generating activity). All media use tracking of user habits to generate advertising and content.

While investigation of the Murdoch empire is warranted by the revelations, prevention of business because of presumed guilt seem contrary to the law and the spirit of the law. The hacking phenomenon seems to cut across several media entities and extending the same logic could mean shutting down significant proportion of the news business in the UK altogether.
It would ironic and poetic justice if the Newscorp empire gets picked on and shut down in the justifiably angry and disgusted public reaction. They've been accused of selectively knocking over politicians and power centres themselves.

I breastfeed on demand, I cosleep, and I also have sex with my husband. It's actually not that difficult. We're not always as sexually active as Ms. Jong would like us to be, but that's mostly because we're busy and tired - not because our son is in our bed. http://www.thegentlemom.com

Tom E and Ravi,

Did you happen to see the twist on a pigpen cipher in TMT?

http://www.themastertheorem.com/theorems/old-mcdonald

BHANG and YEGG were new to me, so much so that I second guessed both of them for a lengthy solving delay.Another non-coffee drinker here, but slang terms for coffee are common and plentiful, so no argument from me. If someone were to do a chocolate themed puzzle, you'd really get my interest!

Allison,

Can you share a bit about how you solve a TMT puzzle? I'm particularly interested in the recent basement puzzle:
http://www.themastertheorem.com/theorems/what-i-do-in-my-basement

Am getting 17, 21, 9 etc for the 7 rows of numbers translated into base 10. Doesn't make sense yet. But I haven't really used some potential clues:
· all bases are used from base 2 to base 8
· numbers are on a column that may wrap around
· these are supposedly 4-digit numbers

So I may be missing some numbers and may have to reorder them. But I'm not sure how to move forward. Can you share a hint or two about how you cracked this one?

USSF ref again -- response to this article about simulating injury. What, if anything, should FIFA do about this issue? Refs do give cautions (yellow cards) for simulation; which is defined in the supplemental materials to the "Laws of the Game" as "attempting to deceive the referee by feigning injury or pretending to be fouled". Refs give yellow cards for faking injury (again, Erika got one) and for players who trip themselves in the penalty area, etc., hoping to get a penalty kick. I've given cards. It's a terrible part of the game, it is cheating. It's lying, and Americans do not like liars. We're seeing it more and more in youth soccer, sadly.
Now, it is true that this happens in all sports. Wide receivers fall over after blown pass plays in American football hoping to get a pass interference call. Baseball players pretend have been hit by a pitch. Basketball players cry out and fall down hoping to draw fouls. Nonetheless, it's a lousy thing for a player to do -- as I said in a previous comment it puts the other players at risk since the ref may hesitate in stopping play and getting treatment for a player who IS hurt. Currently, it is part of the game, but it should not be. In professional matches it seems to me that a video of the match could be reviewed by officials that are trained for this. If a player has obviously simulated an injury, a fine and suspension could be given. This would perhaps not end the practice, but it would certainly make a player think twice. Would Erika have fallen down holding her back with no one around her if she knew there was a possibility she would be banned from a World Cup semi-final?
FIFA does not like to make rules that cannot be followed throughout all of soccer/football. Obviously, not everybody has video re-play. But if FIFA came out strongly against this practice, and did something about it, I think the disdain for simulation would soon filter down to the club and youth levels

Americans are usually generous with charity, so this idea might work. But why should large companies-like Cancer Research UK-also ride the bandwagon? They already have millions and have not yielded much. Time to move over and let the smaller and hopefully independent and sincere scientists have a piece of the pie.
I live in Birmingham,Al and I also know something about the politics around here.Mr Beason does represent his constituents ,bigoted ,racist and tribal.

Americans learn to play the game the wrong way as kids. Look at basketball, all you need is a ball and something to act as a net and you're off. But if you want to play soccer, you need special shoes, pads, uniform, a special ball, a field, and a net.

I grew up in South America, we played football anywhere, with any type of ball and no uniforms. I didn't play on a regulation field until I was 12 years old. I learned the game in the streets, in my backyard, in the halls of my school. I played football the way Americans play basketball. All those killer moves you see in football comes from learning to play in unusual situations much like basketball. Much like learning to play basketball. (The first Basketball game I played was a Rough/21 in Newark, NJ.)

Finally, teaching kids to play long ball at a young age is a waste of time. A player can learn to head the ball when they are older, but they will never be able to learn great ball handling skills when you are older.

All the structural barrier like large fields, and equipment needs to be removed from the game so kids can just start playing. The only other way change American Soccer is to let more immigrant in and I know that's not a popular idea!

It's funny, I never thought of the pressure that comes with the comparison to their "big sisters". Now I can see how it can be a burden and that it's important to, as Lloyd said, 'write your own story.' It's also important for the success of the WPS, which needs its national heroes to fuel the league.
I find the Japanese style of play precise - and boring. But I'd give anything not to see the Swedish do their horrid celebration dance ever again. And of course - GO USA!
I suspect that the Murdoch organization does not bribe government officials as much as it seeks to blackmail them.

I was under the impression that starting at least 20 years ago, places like MIT were working with artifical neural networks and fuzzy logic programs to simulate human like reasoning and decision making of automated systems. Our hardware and software technologies, including massive increases in memory and storage capacity, random access memory, very high speed multi-core cpu's, systems on a chip, fiber optic high speed broadband connections, nanometric circuitry, and access to the immense computing power and information/software resources of the cloud via the internet, should make intelligent robots far more achievable today than back then.

We see an increasing amount of robotic-like automation involving split second decisions in the latest generation of automobiles including accident avoidance automated braking and even lane change assistance. I believe Google is working on a self-driving car (although I am not too thrilled with this idea).
How ironic that Secretary Clinton analogizes the Afghan women to pet rocks, whose interest were cannot honor  at this time, but  urged Obama   to head full tilt into Libya.

Without resorting to a synthesis or to privilege any pole of the opposition, one attempts to bridge the gap between the visible and the invisible in architecture. The experience of seeing the invisible (space) with the construct of the visible (matter) is inherent in this exploration.

The prevailing Aristotelian concept of genesis of idea (eidos) dominates architectural production. Through kinetic paradigm of “point, line and plane”, in conjunction with Cartesian separation of thought, vision and action, it produces cartographic spaces whereby ideas of architecture fulfill their telepathic destiny through the instrumental use of Euclidian Geometry.

This exploration attempts to reveal an other approach by bringing into awareness of the artificial separation of subject/object polarities in a classical conception of making space. Opposing, yet, acknowledging the Cartesian dictum of “I think therefore I am”, the line of mediation between subject and object is brought fore to present the notions of “I think therefore it is” and “ I think therefore we are”, [Kong, Geometry of the Unconscious, PAGEONE publisher Singapore 2011]

So both semifinals pit technical skill and speed against size and direct play. We know where the game is going, the question is does the old guard have one more tournament in them? Japan - Sweden is interesting. For all their possession, Japan struggle to score in run of play. For all of Sweden's size advantage, Japan are faster and hold the ball better. I've no idea how to call this. The great thing is that we'll have a new face in the final!

Several concerns in USA-France. We struggle to get the ball out of defense even without a lot of pressure and we're not good at maintaining possession. If they press high we're going to have issues. Paul's idea of Boxx in the back is interesting, as she does have the size and strength to counter Delie, if the defense is set. If it isn't, all Boxx will see is a clean pair of heels. Thiney, le Sommer, and especially Thomis all have the pace to burn our wings, and Thomis can outrun anyone. If Sundhage starts Lloyd and Boxx in midfield they'll run circles (and triangles) around them. Bini's also good at making adjustments, and they're better than we are at controlling the pace of the game. They're not quite yet a finished product, but I'm glad they're here with their brand of football. Even if this is as far as they get this time around I'm sure we'll be seeing a lot more of them in the future (like London 2012). That's great for the game.

We do have several advantages. Hope Solo, for one. It seems Bini is bringing back Meilleroux (left due to injury in Nigeria match) for Viguier, so one centerback may not be match sharp, and if we can find some finishing sharpness we'll get our chances. Necib is wonderfully elegant and stylish, but kind of lightly built. It's a lot harder to get the ball off her than it is to get her off the ball, and we definitely have a physicality advantage. And finally we have experience in this tournament that they do not. Should be a good match. I just hope it's not an ugly one.

comments.userDisplayName: The Artist Formerly Known As Bakes
comments.userLocation: In the castle of my skin
comments.commentBody:
TDK.. what about Homare Sawa getting kicked in the groin late in the second half and having to be stretchered off in agony. Two minutes later, while Foudy is busy second-guessing the Japanese coach for not subbing her out, onto the field limps Sawa, Willis Reed-esque, still obviously struggling. Not a good ten minutes later she delivers the critical pass that lead to the goal to put her team into the finals. Talk about excelling against the odds, playing the defending champs on their home turf with all of the size and physical advantages.

Yael focused in the Japanese game a lot more than we've been giving it due here in the comments. I really appreciate how comfortable they seem on the ball... nothing rushed, just a quiet composure. If a pass is necessary it comes off at the right time. It that means not holding onto the ball then fine... if holding up play is necessary fine too... and seemingly every midfielder knows how to work herself out of trouble when necessary. Their spatial awareness is incredible to watch.... and I feel a tinge of guilt saying that because it's something we innately expect of the men, but when the women do it... it's like praising our kid brother... or sister :D But guilt aside, I think it's a testament to how adept the women are becoming and for the purist, it's a privilege to be treated to good "football" regardless the gender of the athletes.

OK, I stand corrected.  Following a little research, it actually appears that a hit baseball entering the stands has been considered in at least one legal case to be "abandoned property", which makes it the rightful property of the person who "retrieves" it.

British polity resorts to the bully-pulpit because they know they have no control over whether the BSkyB deal is consummated.  Murdoch should move a-head with the deal.  he has nothing to loose at this point with his news empire beginning to crumble.  I predict the deal will not go through because banks financing it will withdraw.
Murdoch himself should be prosecuted. He must have known about the hacking that had gone on at such a scale and for so long. The buck stopst there. He should go to jail.
Rupert Murdoch and his wife were at a White House dinner a few months ago - how did that happen? What's the connection?

Sure, being ridged and unbending is okay regarding telling the truth or helping the disadvantaged. As a general philosophy of how to conduct ones life those qualities reflect what could most kindly be called a diminished intellect.

The question now is, why is this guy popular with anyone? It turns out he is popular in a very narrow segment of the population that agrees with him. The rest of the people either don't agree with him or they have no opinion and admire the guy for being audacious. Audacious gets tiring in a hurry.
Hmmm...isn't everyone ranting these days about corruption in government, and here is someone willing to go to the mat to convict them. It's gotta count for something...
